resources.string: A command block is a block which you can write console commands.
The block executes a command when it receives a redstone signal.
This block greatly expands the possibilities for creating maps.
The command block cannot be created or found, it can only be accessed through a console command.
To get a command block, type the command (Player - nickname of player): /give Player command_block
For many commands you need to specify the coordinates x,y,z (for example 10, 20, 15) but you can specify the current coordinates using the symbol ~, so you can shift them (for example ~5, ~, ~-10).
tp Player 10 20 30 - teleports player "Player" to a point with x=10, y=20, z=30 coordinates
title @a title "Hello World" - sends a message to all users "Hello World"
Impulse - The usual command block, nothing special, scroll to next.
Chain - Used to create command chains from multiple command blocks
When a signal is given to the first block, the commands in all three blocks are executed. An arrow on the unit indicates the unit that will be activated on.
Repeat - After activation starts very quickly, execute the command in the loop until the Redstone signal disappears.
Activity-used for blocks in a chain. \nAlways Active - the block doesn\'t need a Redstone signal to execute a command. \nNeeds Redstone - vice versa needs a signal.

Condition - used for blocks in the chain. \nConditional - a command in such a block will only execute if the commands in the previous block in the chain succeed. Important: in any case, the following block commands will continue to run. \nUnconditional - the usual block, nothing special.
Build this scheme. By the length of the wire to the light detector depends time of executing block command. Longer the wire - sooner the command is executed.
Copy the command to the block. /time set day
Put two command blocks with buttons.
Copy the command to the first block. fill ~1 ~ ~ ~1 ~ ~-100 minecraft:rail
Copy the command to the second block. fill ~-1 ~ ~ ~-1 ~ ~-100 air
Clicking on the first block activates the railway. Clicking on the second will remove it.
Put the command block with the button
Copy the command to the block. playsound minecraft:block.glass.break master @a

Now, when you press the button, all players will hear the sound of broken glass. You can replace the @a parameter and choose who should hear the sound. Also, you can add the coordinates in which this sound will be heard
Mark the area that will be cleaned and put it on the edge of the command block with a button.
Copy the command to the block and specify the desired territory: fill ~1 ~ ~ ~5 ~20 ~5 air
Press the button - the area is cleaned
Building such a scheme. Everywhere maximum delay.
Copy the command to the block: weather clear
To activate the scheme you need to put a red torch and quickly remove it.
The working scheme looks like this.
Put the command block with the lever. Make it repeatable.
Copy the command to the block: execute at @a run particle minecraft:flame ~ ~ ~ 0.5 0.2 0.5 0.05 10
Now around you there is a fire.
/execute - used to create a complex command with conditions.
The /execute command is divided into subcommands. The subcommands fall into three categories:
Modifier: subcommands that allow you to change the way the command is executed. For example, change the executor and the place of the command execution.
Condition: subcommands that can prevent the command from running. For example, the command will run if a specific entity exists.
Record: subcommands that preserve the result or success of the command.

The /execute command can contain an unlimited number of subcommands, except the run [command]subcommand. This subcommand can be recorded only once at the end of the chain of subcommands. Note that you cannot use / at the beginning of a command written with run.

/ execute align [axis] 
Adjusts the coordinates of the command execution location under the grid of blocks (that is, they are rounded off). 
Example: 
/execute positioned -1.8 2.3 5.9 align x run particle flame: creates a flame particle at coordinates (-2, 2.3, 5.9)

/ execute anchored (feet | eyes) 
Changes the anchor point of the local coordinates of the artist ~ ~ ~. 
Example: 
/execute at @p anchored eyes run setblock ~ ~ ~ 4 diamond_block: puts the diamond block 4 blocks ahead of the level of the eyes of the nearest player.

/ execute as [targets] 
Changes the executor of the command (the execution location itself does not change). If there are several goals, the team will be executed once with each performer. 
Example: 
/execute as @a run say Hello !: performed as if each player executed the command say Hi! with operator rights.

/ execute at [targets] 
Changes the measurement, position and rotation of the command to the same as the goals (the performer does not change). If there are several goals, the command will be executed once with each execution point. 
Example: 
/execute at @p run setblock ~ ~ ~ 2 diamond_block: puts the diamond block ahead of the nearest player.

/ execute facing entity [targets] (eyes | feet) 
Executes the command as if the performer’s gaze is directed at the specified target anchor. If there are several goals, the team will be executed once with each turn of the performer. 
Example: 
/execute as @p at @s anchored eyes facing entity @e [type = cow, limit = 1, sort = nearest] eyes run setblock ~ ~ ~ 5 diamond_block: puts a diamond block between the "eyes" of the nearest player and the "eyes" of the nearest to him a cow in 5 blocks from this player.

/ execute facing [position] 
Executes the command as if the performer’s gaze is directed to the specified position. 
Example: 
/execute as @p at @s facing 0 0 0 run setblock ~ ~ ~ 5 diamond_block: puts a diamond block between the nearest player and the position (0, 0, 0) in 5 blocks from this player.

/ execute in (overworld | the_end | the_nether) 
Changes the dimension in which the command is executed. 
Example: 
/execute as @p in the_nether run teleport 0 64 0: teleports the closest player to the Lower World to the position (0, 64, 0).

/ execute positioned [position] 
Changes the position of the command to the specified position. 
Example: 
/execute positioned 0 64 0 run setblock ~ ~ ~ diamond_block: puts the diamond block to the position (0, 64, 0), but the measurement in which the command is executed is saved.

/ execute positioned as [targets] 
Changes the position of the command to the same as the goals. If there are several goals, the team will be executed once with the position of each goal. 
Example: 
/execute positioned as @p run setblock ~ ~ ~ diamond_block: puts the diamond block at the position of the nearest player, but the measurement in which the command is executed is saved.

/ execute rotated [turn] 
Changes the turn of a command to the specified turn. 
Example: 
/execute at @p rotated ~ 30 0 run setblock ~ ~ ~ 4 diamond_block: puts the diamond block in front of the nearest player, as if its head turn is 30 degrees to the right, and the slope is 0 degrees.

/ execute rotated as [targets] 
Changes the turn of the command to the same as the goals. If there are several goals, the team will be executed once with the turning of each goal. 
Example: 
/execute at @p rotated as @e [type = cow, limit = 1, sort = nearest] run setblock ~ ~ ~ 4 diamond_block: puts the diamond block in front of the nearest player, as if its head turn is the same as that of the nearest cow .

All subcommands listed below contain an argument (if | unless). 
if checks whether the condition is true. If so, the chain continues on. 
unless checks to see if the condition is false. If so, the chain continues on. 
In addition, condition subcommands can be used to get the return value.

/ execute (if | unless) block [position] [block] 
Checks the compliance of the block at the position specified 
Check: 
if: checks the location of the specified block at the specified position. 
unless: checks the location of any block other than the specified position. 
Example: 
/execute if block 0 64 0 diamond_block run say The diamond block !: displays a chat message if it finds a diamond block at the coordinates (0, 64, 0).

/ execute (if | unless) blocks [start] [end] [assignment] (all | masked) 
Checks the consistency of the [start > end] area and the destination area. 
Check: 
if: checks the complete matching of the areas. 
unless: check for mismatch of areas. 
Example: 
/execute if blocks 0 0 0 10 10 10 20 20 20 masked run say Full match !: Displays a chat message if the area [(0, 0, 0) > (10, 10, 10)] fully matches the area [(20 , 20, 20) > (30, 30, 30)].

/ execute (if | unless) entity [entity] 
Checks the existence of an entity in loaded chunks. 
Check: 
if: checks the existence of at least one of the listed entities. 
unless: checks for the existence of any of the entities listed. 
Example: 
/execute if entity @e [type = cow] run say Cow !: Displays a chat message if there is a cow in the loaded chunks.

/execute (if | unless) score [goal] [task-goal] (<| <= | = |> = |>) [source] [task-source] 
Checks the truth of the comparison in the specified way of counting the target in the target problem and the source counting in the source task. 
Check: 
if: checks if the expression is true. 
unless: checks for a lie expression. 
Example: 
/execute if score Alex obj < Steve obj run say Alex < Steve: displays a chat message if Alex's score in the obj task is less than Steve's score in the same task.

/execute (if | unless) score [goal] [task-goal] matches [range] 
Checks whether the target range of the target task is entered. 
Check: 
if: checks if the account is in the range. 
unless: check if the account is out of range. 
Example: 
/execute if score Alex obj matches 1 .. run say Natural number !: displays a chat message if Alex’s score in the obj task is at least 1.

result: records the result of the command. 
success: records the success of the command. 
If the command fails (success is 0), the result will also be 0. 
The value will be recorded when the entire command has completed completely.

/ execute store (result | success) block [position] [path] (byte | double | float | int | long | short) [multiplier] 
Writes the value at the specified path to the NBT data of the entity block located at the specified position as a multiplied number with the specified type. 
Example: 
result block 0 65 0 RecordItem.Count byte 1.5 run scoreboard players get Alex obj: assuming the player is on (0, 65, 0), changes the number of items inserted into it by the value of the Alex account in the obj task multiplied by 1.5.

/ execute store (result | success) bossbar [ID] (value | max) 
Writes the value to the current or maximum value of the bossbar with the specified ID. 
Example: 
foo: bar value run get get entity Alex Health: Writes the value of the NBT tag Health of the player Alex to the current value of the boss bar foo: bar.

/ execute store (result | success) entity [target] [path] (byte | double | float | int | long | short) [multiplier] 
Writes the value at the specified path to the NBT data of the target as a multiplied number with the specified type. 
This subcommand cannot modify player NBT data. NBT data along the path “Inventory [index] .tag” or “EnderItems [index] .tag” is an exception and can be changed. 
Example: 
/execute as @e [type = pig] at @s store entity @s saddle byte 1 if entity @p [distance = .. 5]: if there is a player within a radius of five blocks around the pig, a saddle will be put on her.

/ execute store (result | success) score [goals] [task] 
Writes a value to the goals in the task. 
Example: 
/execute store result score Pigs obj if entity @e [type = pig]: writes the number of pigs found in the loaded chunks to the “Pigs” task of the obj task.
We put the command block with the lever and make it repeatable.
Copy the command to the block. execute at @a run fill ~ ~-1 ~ ~ ~-1 ~ minecraft:gold_block
We put the command block with the lever and make it repeatable.
Copy the command to the block. execute at @a run execute at @e[type=minecraft:creeper,dx=5,dz=5,dy=5] run summon minecraft:lightning_bolt
execute at @a run execute at @e[type=minecraft:creeper,dx=5,dz=5,dy=5] run summon minecraft:lightning_bolt
Activate the block and find the creeper.
In example you can give to near player a gold ingots by command give @p gold_ingot 10
After activation, I have 10 gold ingots in my inventory!
Create scheme as on the screenshot.
Right click to enter the block.
Copy the command to the top line
Press the lever and the command will be executed.
To impose any effects on the character you need to use the command " effect"
For example, regeneration for 10 seconds with a force of 1 heart per second will be applied by the command: effect give @p regeneration 10 1
To put a block you need to use the setblock command. For example, the command "setblock ~ ~ ~ minecraft:bricks replace" will put a brick block in the world coordinates.
You can change the game mode with the gamemode command. For example, to log on to survival, use the command "gamemode survival @r"

To give experience, you need the experience team. This team can give out a certain amount of experience or levels. For example, the "experience add @p 100 levels" command will raise the nearest player to 100

To cause some kind of particles like fire bursts or clods of dirt when you run, you need to use the "particle"command. For example, to call a spark from lava you need to use the command "particle minecraft:lava ~ ~ ~"
To call some creature to the point, you need to use the command "summon". Example for call pigs "summon pig ~ ~1 ~"
This command will be useful if you need to quickly fill some rooms with blocks. For example, we can quickly fill a room with water
Type the command: fill ~-10 ~-1 ~-10 ~10 ~-1 ~10 minecraft:water keep
To get everything back, change "keep" to "replace" and add "minecraft:air". "fill ~-10 ~-1 ~-10 ~10 ~-1 ~10 minecraft:air replace minecraft:water"
To invoke lightning, use the command " summon minecraft: lightning_bolt ~ ~ ~"
Move from "Impulse" to "Repeat" to get a lot of lightning
To play a friend, you can use the command "fill". Instead of PlayerName you need to write player\'s nickname "execute at PlayerName run fill ~-2 ~10 ~-2 ~2 ~12 ~2 minecraft:sand"
execute at PlayerName run fill ~-2 ~10 ~-2 ~2 ~12 ~2 minecraft:sand
The sand is dropped from a height!
How to kill a lot of mobs
You need to use the "kill" command, and set the type of mob, for example pigs "kill @e[type= minecraft:pig]"
All pigs in the radius of the load was lost.
To enchant an object, take it in hand
Apply command "enchant PlayerName minecraft: sharpness 3" for sharpness
To get an achievement, you need to use the command "advance" advance grant zeon only minecraft: end/kill_dragon"
Do you have a pen and all the sheep have run away?
You can make two blocks to change the difficulty with one click. "difficulty hard" for hard mode.
To change the daily rhythms you need to use the team gamerule. Assemble the circuit to switch them. To enable "gamerule doDaylightCycle true"
Build a scheme to switch the two command blocks
In one put the command for half a day "time set noon"
The second command for midnight. "time set midnight"
Build an altar as on the screen
Put the gold plate next to the command block
Activate the plate by offering a bar of gold
Enter the command "execute at @e run fill ~ ~-1 ~ ~ -1 ~-1 ~ minecraft:sand" into the command block to make all creatures turn blocks into sand
